SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRES

No. 1

PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

A word of explanation to the person answering this questionnaire:

It is difficult to prepare a general questionnaire on pioneer life because no individual who is asked to answer it has exactly the same experiences as another. Some of the questions here will not apply to your experiences; others may prove impossible for you to answer, so don't worry about leaving blank spaces. Use extra sheets of paper if there is not sufficient space to answer the questions. Don't hesitate to give details, or describe particular events, if they help to answer the questions.

This questionnaire is intended for persons who lived in Western Canada before 1914, and may be answered by anyone who has personal experience of the pioneer years whether born in this province or not.

If more than one member of the family can answer the questions, they should write them on separate sheets or apply for a separate questionnaire.

Other Questionnaires

Saskatchewan Archives Questionnaire No. 1, entitled "Pioneer Diet: What Did Western Canadian Pioneers Eat?" is still being circulated. If you have not already answered this, and would be willing to do so, please put a check mark here ( ) and one will be sent to you.

Saskatchewan Archives questionnaires on other subjects will be prepared at a later date. Some of these are listed below. Please mark the ones you would be willing to answer.

( ) All questionnaires
( ) Pioneer health conditions
( ) Pioneer social life, sports and recreation
( ) Pioneer housing
( ) Pioneer education and churchwork
( ) Pioneer farming experience

Preservation of Questionnaires

All questionnaires will be preserved in the Saskatchewan Archives Board's Office at the University of Saskatchewan as part of the permanent record of our Province. Please send your completed questionnaire to:

Saskatchewan Archives Office,
University of Saskatchewan,
Saskatoon, Sask.

PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

A MEETING OF EXHIBITORS TO THE PROVINCE

It is difficult to prepare a general questionnaire on pioneer life because no individual who has lived in exactly the same environment as another can answer all questions. It is not necessary to answer every question; others may prove impossible for you to answer and you should not worry about leaving blank spaces. The questions are intended for persons who lived in Western Canada before 1921, and may be answered by anyone who has personal experience of the pioneer years whether born in this province or not.

If more than one member of the family can answer the questions, they should write them on separate sheets or apply for a separate questionnaire.

PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

NOTE: Please print all proper names and place names in capital letters. If you are not sure the name is correct as you have given it, please say so. If you'd rather have someone else do the writing at your dictation, this is quite acceptable.

1. Your full name: NORMAN MACDONALD
2. Your address: R.R. No. 2, Wapella, Sask.
3. Date: April 9th, 1957
4. Where were you born? (Give name of place and country): Benbecula, Inverness Shire, Scotland
5. What was your father's name and occupation?: Robert MacDonnell, Stone Mason
6. When did you come to Saskatchewan? (Give month and year): May, 1883
7. Mention any other places where you lived before coming to Saskatchewan, giving dates wherever possible.

8. How old were you when you first came to Western Canada? (You do not need to answer this question if you would rather not or you may use "I was a small child", "I was in my teens", etc). 10 years

9. What were your reasons for coming West?
   My father had only a small craft,
   and he thought he could better himself by coming to Canada with his family.

10. How did you learn about the West? (Through other people? Reading about it? Railroad or government information)?
    Leslie Gordon Cathcart, owner of the Island of Benbecula from which we surveyed out Macdonald MacDermid over to Canada in 1881 to look over the country to see if he considered it a suitable place to settle and he gave a very favorable report when he went back to Scotland. So that how we came out here. Mr. MacDermid died some years ago; he was the man that took the 1883 settlers and notably Cathcart.

2. Your full name: NORMAN MACDONALD

3. Date: April 9th, 1953

4. Where were you born? (Give name of place and country) Bendale, America

5. What was your father's trade and occupation? Rancher

6. When did you come to Saskatchewan? (Give month and year) May 1883

7. Mention any other places where you lived before coming to Saskatchewan, giving dates wherever possible.

8. How old were you when you first came to Western Canada? (You do not need to answer this question if you would rather not or you may use if was a small child)

9. What were your reasons for coming West?

My father had only a small cattle farm, my mother had a small cattle farm, and my family was moving to Canada with his family.

10. How did you learn about the West? (Through other people? Reading about it? Railroad or government information?)

Lady Gordon Macdonald, our dear aunt, of Bendale, Saskatchewan, was a Canadian. In 1881 she came to Canada by way of Prince Albert. She came here because it was a good place to live and she came to work there. My parents went to Canada because they heard it was a good place to live and work.
11. What did your friends and relatives think of your decision to come to Western Canada?

12. Did you travel by yourself or with a party (family, friends or other groups)?
   I came out with my parents.

13. What means of transportation did you use?
   Steamsips and railroad

14. What incidents of the journey West do you remember? (People you met on the way,
    meetings with Indians, adventures on the journey, accidents or other excitement etc.)
   I met many Indians and they were always friendly

15. Where did you first stay when you arrived in Saskatchewan?
   On the Banks of the Pipestone Creek Nine Miles South of Wapella

16. Where did you settle or take up land?
   In this locality

17. Mention any other places where you have lived since coming to Saskatchewan.

18. How did you earn a living before coming to Western Canada? How after you came?

19. How often did you write to relatives or friends in your old home?

Still corresponding with them.

20. If you got married, give the name of your husband or wife along with the date and place of marriage.

First wife, Anna Graham
Married 1900. Married my second wife,
Flora McDonald in 1928.

21. Did anyone else come to Montana because of you, recommending it as a place to settle? My first wife died with the flu in 1919.

22. If other members of your family (brothers, sisters, parents, etc.) came West tell when they came and where they settled.

All around in this district.

23. Is there any particular experience of pioneer days that stand out in your memory which you would like to record?

In 1883 we built a sod shack and it was burned down, and we lost the most of our clothes. We built a log house before winter set in. It was on 7th farm that we planted potatoes on land barely broken and had a very crop, we also put in a few acres of barley and oats. The barley crop was good but our wheat crop we could not harvest before the frost came.

24. Did you travel about much in the early years? (for business, attending church, visiting friends, etc.) How often? How far? by what means of travel?

We all went to church and visiting friends, our mode of travel was by a yoke of oxen and wagon.

29. How often did you shop in the early days?
   *about every two weeks*

30. When (if ever) did people in your district first start going to town regularly on Saturdays?
   *1938*

31. When (if ever) did you first begin to buy through the mail order catalogues? What kind of articles did you buy in this way? Indicate also what fraction of your total purchases were by mail order and any changes in the proportion of purchases made by mail order since the pioneer period.
   *Forty years ago we bought from the mail order houses. It was mostly clothing and harness materials. We bought less than 20% of our purchases from mail order houses.*

32. When did you first have a telephone and what company provided it?

33. When you came to Saskatchewan the first time was it with the idea of staying permanently? Or did you make up your mind after trying it out? When did you make this decision?
   *We came here to stay*
